 I think the best term for it is political correctness. 
 
 The world is far more complicated than the day is long, and the nature of news reporting and distribution has dictated that one source generally sets the tone for what will be reported each day, and that source is the New York Times.
 
 
The New York Times is arguably the most influential media outlet in America. Not only is it the most influential newspaper in the media capital of the world, New York City, but it is also read nationwide and frequently sets the agenda for the television news programs from which most Americans get their news. 

 
 Example; If a black man with a white woman companion has a hate crime commited against him in the southern US, it will be reported to a far greater extent than would a white man with a black woman companion having a hate crime committed against him on the streets on New York City (or anywhere else for that matter). There are many documented examples of this type of omission of news.
 
 
 IMO the situation described in post #1 didn't come about throughout the general population in a natural way, it has trickled in starting with the NYT, through most news media outlets, including daytime TV like PBS and Oprah. 
 
 Political correctness is the result of a combination of omissions of some news, and sensationalism of others. It sells.
